Large-scale exploitation of natural gas and shale gas has spurred the development of the propane dehydrogenation technology. While cobalt-based catalysts, known for their low cost and low toxicity, effectively activate C–H bonds, they are often deactivated because of coke formation. In this study, we prepared SBA-15 molecular sieves using a hydrothermal synthesis method and developed a series of Co-based catalysts supported on SBA-15 with various metal promoters (denoted Co-X/SBA-15, where X = Mn, Fe, Mg, Zn, or La) via an incipient wetness impregnation method. Characterization techniques and activity evaluation results revealed that the Co–O–Mg structure in the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst stabilizes the primary Co2+ active site and hinders the reduction of the CoOx species. The incorporation of Mg enhances the total alkalinity of the catalyst, facilitating propane adsorption and propylene desorption, leading to superior activity and stability. Although the addition of La improved propylene selectivity, it did not significantly enhance propane conversion. Conversely, the introduction of Mn, Fe, and Zn into the catalyst inhibited the reaction. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane dehydrogenation Catalytic promoters SBA-15 Cobalt-based catalysts Abbreviations PDH propane dehydrogenation P123 poly (ethylene oxide)-block-poly (propylene oxide)-block-poly (ethylene oxide) TEOS tetraethyl orthosilicate BET Brunauer–Emmett–Teller FE-SEM field emission scanning electron microscope HR-TEM high-resolution transmission electron microscope XRD X-ray diffraction SEM scanning electron microscopy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propene is a fundamental raw material for producing polypropylene, propylene oxide, acrylonitrile, acrolein, acetone, and various high-value-added chemicals and intermediates. It is primarily manufactured through petroleum-derived steam cracking, fluid catalytic cracking, and methanol-to-propylene processes [1,2]. However, issues such as low olefin selectivity and limited fossil fuel energy resources have created a supply-demand imbalance for propene. The large-scale exploitation of natural gas and shale gas has propelled the development of propane dehydrogenation (PDH) technologies. Currently, approximately 10% of the global propene supply comes from PDH reactions, owing to their numerous advantages such as high propene selectivity, absence of byproducts, cost-effectiveness, and abundant raw material sources [3]. Currently, Pt- [4–7] and Cr- [8–13] based catalysts are widely used for PDH reactions, both domestically and internationally. However, Pt is expensive, and Cr is toxic and environmentally unfriendly. Therefore, there is an urgent need to identify active metals that are both low-cost and environmentally friendly. Co has garnered considerable attention from researchers owing to its abundant reserves, low cost, relatively low toxicity, and excellent selective dehydrogenation properties. Nevertheless, Co-based catalysts are still in the research stage, with their catalytic mechanisms not yet fully understood or implemented in industrial settings [14]. Sun et al. [15] investigated the performance of Co/Al2O3 catalysts with varying Co3O4 loadings for the catalytic dehydrogenation of propane. At a loading of 5 wt.%, these catalysts exhibited a propylene yield of 21.5% and a selectivity of 83.6%. Moreover, incorporating promoters can strengthen the interaction between the active metal and support. Zhang et al. [16] successfully developed a 5Co1.6Fe/Al2O3 catalyst by doping an Al2O3-supported Co catalyst with 1.6 wt% Fe. This doping effectively inhibited Co reduction and enhanced both the activity and selectivity of the Co catalyst in propane dehydrogenation. Furthermore, it significantly improved the durability of the Co catalyst, achieving an optimal propane conversion of 22.4% and propylene selectivity of 97.3%. Fan et al. [17] developed a Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst and utilized it in a PDH reaction. After 6 h of reaction, while the propane conversion rate decreased slightly from 51.2% to 49.3%, the propylene selectivity remained above 97%. This phenomenon was attributed to the optimal amount of Mn doping in the Pt/10Mn-SBA-15 catalyst, which stabilized the highly dispersed Pt active sites by enhancing the metal–support interactions, thereby boosting its PDH performance. Xue [18] developed a Co/1.5Mg/S-1 catalyst with an initial propane conversion rate of 5.9%. The addition of Mg as a promoter increased the overall alkalinity of the catalyst, promoted the desorption of propylene, and ultimately enhanced its catalytic performance. Because Co-based catalysts often suffer from low propylene yields and insufficient stability, this study employed SBA-15 molecular sieves synthesized using a hydrothermal method as the catalyst support. To bolster the stability of the active component Co2+, we introduced Mn, Fe, Mg, Zn, and La as promoters during the preparation process. These promoters were added at a concentration of 1.5 wt%. These additives were incorporated to enhance the activity, selectivity, and stability of Co2+ by fostering interactions between the metals and the support. Furthermore, this study delved into the synergistic interactions between the active component Co2+ and metal promoters, investigating their impact on the performance of the catalysts during PDH reactions. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation The SBA-15 molecular sieves were synthesized using the following method. First, a certain amount of poly (ethylene oxide)-block-poly (propylene oxide)-block-poly (ethylene oxide) (P123) was mixed with concentrated hydrochloric acid and deionized water in a beaker. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred in a water bath at 40 °C for 1 h until P123 was completely dissolved. Next, a specific quantity of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) solution was added dropwise to this mixture and stirred in the water bath at 40 °C for 24 h. Next, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave for hydrothermal synthesis and crystallized at 120 °C for 24 h. After crystallization, the resulting precipitate was washed sequentially with ethanol and water, followed by drying in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Subsequently, a molecular sieve containing the templating agent was placed in a muffle furnace and heated to 550 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. The sieve was then calcined for 5 h to remove the templating agent. Finally, SBA-15 molecular sieves were obtained with the following molar ratio of reactants: TEOS: P123: HCl: H2O = 1:0.017:6:138. The Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts (where X = Fe, Mn, La, Zn, or Mg; with mass fractions of 1.5 wt%) were prepared using the following method. A certain amount of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and (Fe, Mn, La, Zn, Mg) metal salts were dissolved in a certain amount of deionized water, and then added drop by drop to SBA-15 using the equal volume impregnation method. The catalyst was then added drop by drop into the SBA-15 carrier and ultrasonicated in an ultrasonic cleaner for 1 h to make the dispersion more homogeneous. This mixture was then allowed to stand at room temperature for 12 h, dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and roasted at 550 °C for 6 h (temperature increase rate: 2 °C/min). The mass fraction of Co in the catalysts was 2.0 wt%, and the catalysts were labeled as Co-Fe/SBA-15, Co-Mn/SBA-15, Co-La/SBA-15, Co-Zn/SBA-15, and Co-Mg/SBA-15 according to the different types of the doped metal additives. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The Co and metal additive contents in the series of synthesized catalysts were determined using a Platinum Elmer Optima 8000 emission spectrometer equipped with inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The physical phase, crystallinity, and dispersion of the active components of the catalyst carriers were determined using a Bruker D8ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany), with Cu Kα radiation, a tube voltage of 40 kV, and a tube current of 40 mA. The specific surface areas, pore volumes, pore diameters, and pore size distributions of the catalysts were determined using a fully automatic N2 adsorption analyzer (model: ASAP2460, manufactured by Micromeritics Builder Tech, United States). The pore diameters and pore size distribution of the samples were determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda-Hong-Kong (BJHHK) ethod, and their specific surface area were determined based on the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. Thesurface morphology of the samples was observed usinga JSM-7800 (Prime) in situ ultra-high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM). The experiments were conducted at accelerating voltages of 10–30 kV and beam intensities of 1–500 nA (30 kV) and 20 nA (2 kV). A detailed morphological analysis of the self-synthesized carrier and catalyst was conducted using a Talos high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) manufactured by Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. Qualitative analysis was then performed to investigate the distribution and elemental composition of the active metals. The catalysts were also analyzed using an automatic chemical adsorption analyzer (model: PCA-1200) produced by Beijing Builder Electronic Technology Co., Ltd. The chemical valence state of Co in the catalyst was determined using X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi, Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States). Using the newly launched TGA8000™ thermogravimetric analyzer from PerkinElmer, the relationship between the mass of the catalyst after reaction and temperature was determined. 2.3 Evaluation of catalyst activity The catalytic performance of PDH at atmospheric pressure was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor with a quartz tube (6 mm inner diameter). In this reaction, 400 mg of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was used. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in H2 for 2 h at 600 °C. The ratio of C3H8 to N2 was 1:2, and the total flow rate was 15 mL/min. The reaction temperature was 630 °C. The products were analyzed online using an SP-3420A gas chromatography instrument equipped with a KB-Al2O3/Na2SO4 capillary column (50 m × 0.32 mm × 10 μm) and an FID detector. Propane conversion (Conv. (C3H8)), propylene selectivity (Sel. (C3H6)), and propylene yield (Yield (C3H6)) were calculated using the following equations [19]: (1) Conv . ( C 3 H 8 ) ( % ) = ( [ C 3 H 8 ] in − ( [ C 3 H 8 ] out ) / ( [ C 3 H 8 ] in × 100 % (2) Sel . ( C 3 H 6 ) ( % ) = [ C 3 H 6 ] / ( [ C 3 H 8 ] i n ) / [ C 3 H 8 ] out ) × 100 % (3) Yield ( C 3 H 6 ) ( % ) = [ C 3 H 6 ] / [ C 3 H 8 ] in × 100 % where [C3H8]in and [C3H8]out represent the propane concentrations in the inlet and outlet gas streams, respectively, and [C3H6] represents the propylene concentration in the outlet gas stream. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Analysis of metal content in the catalysts The doping amounts of the metal additives and the loading of the active metal (Co) in the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts were determined using ICP-OES (Table 1 ). According to Table 1, the actual loading of Co exceeded 1.91 wt%, while the doping amount of the metal additive element X was above 1.42% for all catalysts. 3.2 Texture property and phase structure Fig. 1 a shows the small-angle XRD patterns of Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts doped with different metal additives. All the prepared catalysts exhibited a diffraction peak at 2θ ≈ 0.6°–0.75°, which corresponds to the characteristic (100) peak. Additionally, two secondary peaks were observed at approximately 2θ = 1.0° and 1.9°, representing the (110) and (200) characteristic peaks, respectively [20]. This indicates that the loading of Co and doping with metal additives such as Fe, Mn, La, Zn, and Mg did not disrupt the ordered structure of the SBA-15 support. When the catalyst was doped with Mg, the position of the (100) peak shifted towards a lower angle range, suggesting that the pore size of the catalyst was larger than that of the other catalysts [21]. This result demonstrates that doping with Mg allows for more uniform dispersion of the active metal without blocking the pores, which is beneficial for propane adsorption and propylene desorption. As shown in Fig. 1b, the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts doped with different metal additives, no reflexes characteristic of any Co-containing crystalline phase could be identified in the XRD patterns of as-prepared catalysts. This indicates that the active metal Co in the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts was uniformly dispersed and did not exhibit aggregation. The structural properties of the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts were investigated using N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. 2 ). All samples exhibited typical type-IV adsorption–desorption curves accompanied by H1 hysteresis loops, indicating typical mesoporous structural adsorption characteristics with a relatively wide pore-size distribution, primarily concentrated between 7 and 14 nm. When catalysts doped with additives such as Zn, Mn, Fe, and La were tested, the hysteresis loops shifted slightly to the left, indicating a decrease in the pore size, which is consistent with the results of small-angle XRD. In contrast, the Mg-doped catalyst exhibited larger pores without blockage of the pore channels. Table 2 presents the textural parameters of the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts, including their specific surface areas and average pore diameters. Compared to Co/SBA-15, the specific surface areas of all the catalysts decreased by varying degrees after the addition of the promoters. Among them, Co-Mg/SBA-15 exhibited the smallest specific surface area of 486.4 m2∙g−1, while Co-Fe/SBA-15 had the largest specific surface area of 560.5 m2∙g−1. The pore volume of catalysts doped with La and Fe increased, while it decreased for those doped with Mg, Zn, and Mn. Notably, Co-Fe/SBA-15 exhibited a relatively large pore volume of 1.084 cm3·g−1. Co-Mg/SBA-15 exhibited the highest pore diameter (9.40 nm), which is consistent with the results of small-angle XRD.As the size of mesopores increases, it becomes more favorable for the entry of active metals, the adsorption of reactants, and the desorption of products, thus enhancing the catalytic performance. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms indicated that all metal promoters (Mg, Zn, Mn, Fe, and La) entered the pores of the SBA-15 support, thereby affecting the catalytic performance. 3.3 Analysis of the microscopic morphology of the catalysts The morphological characteristics of the catalysts were observed using high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Fig. 3 ). All samples exhibited a two-dimensional hexagonal strip structure. These results, combined with the XRD characterization results, confirm the successful synthesis of the SBA-15 molecular sieve. Furthermore, the structure of the molecular sieve was not destroyed after loading the active metal Co and doping with promoters, thus maintaining the two-dimensional hexagonal structure. Fig. 3 also shows the distribution of Co and metal promoter elements in the five Co-based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3, Co is uniformly distributed in all five catalysts, with good dispersion and dispersion effect is close, consistent with the XRD results. Owing to the low loading of Co and its highly uniform distribution, no characteristic diffraction peaks of CoOx species were detected in the wide-angle XRD patterns, further proving the uniform dispersion of Co. 3.4 Analysis of the fine structure and species morphology of the catalysts The fine structures of the catalysts were obtained using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to assess the effect of Mg addition on the dispersion of Co on SBA-15. The HRTEM images of the SBA-15 molecular sieve and Co-Mg/SBA-15 (Fig. 4 ) reveal that the prepared SBA-15 molecular sieve exhibited a two-dimensional hexagonal structure and that the ordered mesoporous structure of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst was well preserved. By comparing the top-view micrographs of SBA-15 and Co-Mg/SBA-15 (Fig. 4), the particles located within the pores can be clearly observed, as indicated by the dashed circles. Based on TEM-mapping, the active component Co was uniformly distributed on the SBA-15 support without aggregation after the addition of the Mg promoter, which is consistent with XRD results. Furthermore, the pore diameter of Co-Mg/SBA-15 measured from the HRTEM image was 9.40 nm, and its wall thickness was 4.04 nm. These results agreed well with the data obtained from the N2 adsorption–desorption characterization. 3.5 Analysis of catalyst reducibility H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) is a technique used to identify the reduction behavior of reducible metal oxides and estimate the interaction between the active phase and the support [22]. As shown in Fig. 5 , a weak H2 consumption peak at 354 °C was observed for Co/SBA-15, indicating the presence of a small amount of CoOx species on the catalyst. The second hydrogen consumption peak observed at 661 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Co2+ to compounds such as Co2SiO4, which suggests a strong interaction between CoOx and the support. After the addition of Mn, La, and Fe as metal promoters, the reduction peak at approximately 354 °C shifted towards higher temperatures, and the peak intensity also increased, indicating the partial reduction of the promoters. Additionally, the introduction of Fe and Zn resulted in the appearance of broad temperature-spanning reduction peaks at approximately 504 °C and 582 °C, respectively, suggesting that Fe and Zn species are difficult to reduce from higher oxidation states to lower or even zero oxidation states. The hydrogen consumption peak of Co-Fe/SBA-15 at 401 °C may have originated from the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and/or CoO to Co, while the peak at 520 °C can be attributed to the reduction of FeO to Fe [23]. For the Co-Mn/SBA-15 catalyst, continuous H2 consumption peaks were observed in the temperature range of 200–500 °C, which can be attributed to the continuous reduction of Co3O4 to Co through a CoO intermediate [24,25]. The peak at nearby 350 °C corresponds to the reduction of MnOx to MnO, and the MnOx reduction peak overlaps with the multi-step reduction peaks of cobalt oxides [26]. For the Co-Zn/SBA-15 catalyst, hydrogen consumption peaks were observed at reduction temperatures of 400–600 °C. The peak at a lower reduction temperature of 400 °C indicates that Co3+ is more easily reduced to Co2+, while the peak at 600 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co2+ to Co0, which requires more energy. The reduction ability of the catalyst was influenced by the dispersion of Co and the interaction between the support material and the Co component. The higher the dispersion of Co, the stronger its interaction with the support material, resulting in a higher reduction temperature [27]. The higher reduction temperature of Co-Zn/SBA-15 compared to that of Co/SBA-15 indicates that Zn assists in the dispersion of Co. For the Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst, the temperature peak before 360 °C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to Co2+ and then Co2+ to Co [28]. The hydrogen consumption peak at approximately 500 °C is attributed to the reduction of LaCoO3 perovskite to an intermediate perovskite with an oxygen-deficient structure [29]. For the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst, the reduction peaks between 310 and 450 °C correspond to the reduction of the active component without the formation of interactions with Mg metal or the support. Table 3 lists the amount of hydrogen consumed by the seven catalysts. Among them, Co-Mg/SBA-15 stood out with the lowest hydrogen consumption compared to the catalysts doped with other promoters. Contrast with Co/SBA-15, the hydrogen consumption of Co-Mg/SBA-15 increased by 0.0492 mmol/g because of the reduction of MgO. The Mg/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited a hydrogen consumption of 0.0585 mmol/g, differing by 0.0093 mmol/g. It indicated that a considerable portion of cobalt (Co) remained unreduced in the catalyst. This is contributed to addition of Mg to the catalyst forms a stable Co–O–Mg structure [30,31], which hinders the reduction process and stabilization of the active Co2+ sites. 3.6 Evaluation of the dehydrogenation performance of catalysts Fig. 6 and 7 show the propane conversion and propylene selectivity curves for the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts, respectively. Fig. 6S shows the graphs of propane conversion and propylene selectivity for Co/SBA-15 and SBA-15 catalysts. Co-Mg/SBA-15, which incorporates Mg species, exhibited excellent propane dehydrogenation capability, with the highest initial propane conversion rate of 41.19% and propylene selectivity of 91.57%. After 10 h of reaction, the conversion rate decreased to 29.22% with a selectivity of 87.23%, indicating a 11.96% decrease in the propane conversion rate. Although Co-La/SBA-15 showed a maximum propane conversion rate of only 14.35%, it exhibited a propylene selectivity of 91.65%, making it the best propylene selectivity among the five catalysts. As shown in Figs. 6 and 7, the initial propylene selectivity of the catalysts doped with different promoters exceeded 87.5%. The Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst doped with La exhibited an inhibitory effect and was not conducive to PDH. The catalytic performances of Co-Fe/SBA-15, Co-Zn/SBA-15, and Co-Mn/SBA-15 were found to be comparable. Although the initial propane conversion rate of Co-Mn/SBA-15 was similar to that of Co-Fe/SBA-15, there was a significant difference in their propane conversion rates after 300 min of reaction, with a difference of 3.81% at the end of the reaction. This is because Co-Fe/SBA-15 has a larger specific surface area and higher Co metal dispersion than Co-Mn/SBA-15, which is more conducive to the PDH reaction and improves the propane conversion rate. The propane conversion rate of Co-Zn/SBA-15 differed from that of Co-Fe/SBA-15 by 6.92% within the first 120 min; however, its conversion rate was slightly higher than that of Co-Fe/SBA-15 between 120 and 300 min. Nevertheless, the conversion rate of Co-Fe/SBA-15 showed a downward trend similar to that of Co-Mn/SBA-15 within 300–600 min. The difference in the catalytic dehydrogenation activity of propane can be attributed to the larger pore diameter and volume of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst, which allowed the active components to enter and adhere to the pores smoothly, enabling the catalyst to have a more effective reaction area. Among this series of catalysts, Co–Mg/SBA-15 demonstrated the lowest hydrogen consumption because Mg forms a Co–O–Mg structure with Co, which is difficult to reduce. Consequently, the reduction of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst is challenging. This helps maintain the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Studies have shown [18] that the addition of an Mg promoter can increase the total alkalinity of the catalyst, promote the desorption of propylene, and improve its catalytic performance. 3.7 Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 CO2-TPD technique is widely used for determination of surface basicity of solid catalysts. The results of CO2-TPD studies of all prepared cobalt catalysts were displayed in Fig. 8 The peaks below 300 °C were attributed to desorption of CO2 from weak basic sites; the peaks at the temperature interval of 300–550 °C were attributed to desorption of CO2 from moderate basic sites. As from the figure, after adding the promoter Mg, the peak areas at weak and medium basicity significantly increase, indicating that the introduction of metal Mg has altered the macroscopic basic properties (base amount and base strength) of the catalyst support, thereby enhancing the number of basic sites on the catalyst. 3.8 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The surface chemical states of the catalysts were studied using XPS. As shown in Fig. 9 , the samples obtained before and after the reduction of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst exhibit two broad and asymmetric main peaks at 775–793 eV and 793–810 eV, respectively, corresponding to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 peaks of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst, respectively. The percentage content of each species was calculated based on the fitting of the peak areas, as shown in Table 4 . After reduction, the peak of metallic Co appeared in the XPS spectrum of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst, specifically Co0 (BE = 780.1 eV) [32,33]. As shown in Fig. 9 and Table 4, the content of both reduced Co0 and Co2+ increased, indicating that a portion of Co3O4 with low binding energy in the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst was reduced to Co2+, and some metallic Co was generated. Before and after reduction, the Co2p3/2 peaks of both samples showed peaks at a high binding energy of 782.8 eV [34,35], corresponding to the Co2+ species in compounds such as Co–O–Mg. Moreover, the peak at a low binding energy of 781.5 eV [36,37] corresponds to the Co3+ ions in Co3O4. The XPS spectrum of the reduced catalyst revealed a stronger satellite peak for Co2+, indicating a decrease in the Co3+ content and an increase in the Co2+ content after reduction. The reduced catalyst, which contained a large amount of Co2+ species and some metallic Co, was conducive to improving propane conversion and propylene selectivity. 3.9 Catalyst carbon deposition analysis Fig. 10 presents the TG-DTG profiles of the Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts after 10 h of PDH reaction. As shown in Fig. 10a, the Co-Zn/SBA-15 catalyst exhibits the largest weight loss, indicating the highest amount of carbon deposition on this catalyst. Based on the H2-TPR profiles and activity results, it is evident that among this series of catalysts, the Co-Zn/SBA-15 catalyst had the highest hydrogen consumption. This allowed the CoOx species to be easily reduced to Co0, resulting in significant side reactions involving C–C bond breakage and the formation of a large amount of byproducts. The DTG profile revealed a weight-loss peak in the low-temperature region, indicating that carbon deposition occurred on the active metal. Propane is more prone to overcracking and deep dehydrogenation reactions on this catalyst, leading to the highest carbon deposition and lowest propylene selectivity after 120 min. This finding aligns with the results of the catalyst evaluation. Compared to Co-Zn/SBA-15, the Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited the lowest weight loss in the DTG profile, indicating minimal carbon deposition. According to the activity results, although the Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst exhibits the lowest propane conversion rate among this series of catalysts, it exhibits the highest propylene selectivity. This suggests that side reactions are least likely to occur on this catalyst and that propylene desorption is more favorable for the Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst. Consequently, the amount of carbon deposited on the catalyst is minimal. Compared to the Co-La/SBA-15 catalyst, the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst exhibits a slightly higher carbon deposition level. This was attributed to the higher conversion rate of the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst, which resulted in a large volume of propane gas reacting at the active sites on the catalyst surface and within its pores. As the reaction time increased, the dehydrogenation activity of the catalyst remained the highest, leading to the production of more propylene, but also potentially increasing the formation of carbon deposition precursors [35]. However, the larger pore diameter of Co-Mg/SBA-15 favored propane adsorption and propylene desorption. Two main types of carbon deposition occur on catalysts: carbon deposition on the active components, represented by a low-temperature weight loss, and carbon deposition on the support, represented by a high-temperature weight loss. As shown in Fig. 9b, the total amounts of carbon deposited on the Co-Zn/SBA-15 and Co-Fe/SBA-15 catalysts were similar, but the deposition locations differed. Carbon deposition on the active sites of the Co-Fe/SBA-15 catalyst is more prominent than that on the Co-Zn/SBA-15 catalyst. This may be due to the high propane conversion rate of Co-Fe/SBA-15 during the initial reaction stage, which is accompanied by an increase in carbon deposition. As the reaction time increases, some active sites are covered, leading to a more rapid decrease in propane conversion. Although both the Co-Mn/SBA-15 and Co-Fe/SBA-15 catalysts exhibited two weight loss peaks, more carbon was deposited on the active sites of the Co-Mn/SBA-15 catalyst. Therefore, the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst demonstrated stronger resistance to carbon deposition, less carbon accumulation, and lower coverage of active sites during the reaction. This facilitated the participation of more active sites in the PDH reaction. 3.10 Structural analysis of the catalyst after of reaction To observe whether the structure of the catalyst was damaged and whether there was aggregation of the active metals after 10 h of reaction, wide-angle XRD was conducted (Fig. 11 ). No characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to Co3O4 were observed for any of the catalysts, indicating that no metal aggregation occurred in the catalysts after the reaction. Furthermore, the structure of the catalysts did not change after the reaction, and a characteristic peak corresponding to amorphous SiO2 appeared at 2θ = 23.5°, indicating that the SBA-15 support possesses high thermal stability. The changes in the surface morphologies of the catalysts after the catalytic performance tests were investigated using TEM. Fig. 12 shows that all the samples retained a well‐ordered mesoporous structure even after reaction for several hours. Coke species were found on the surfaces of the spent Co/SBA‐15 and Co-Mg/SBA‐15 catalysts. As can be seen from the figure, the waste catalyst Co-Mg/SBA-15 doped with the promoter Mg shows reduced coke deposition, which enhanced the catalyst stability during propane dehydrogenation. 4 Conclusion The Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst prepared via equal-volume impregnation exhibited superior catalytic performance compared to other Co-X/SBA-15 catalysts, achieving a maximum propane conversion rate of 41.19% and a propylene selectivity of 91.57%. The incorporation of Mg as a promoter led to the formation of a stable Co–O–Mg structure among the metals, resulting in the lowest hydrogen consumption among this series of catalysts. This demonstrates that Mg enhances the dispersion of the active component Co, enabling more Co atoms to exist in the stable Co2+ form. This makes catalyst reduction challenging and contributes to maintaining the catalytic performance of the catalyst. Additionally, Co2+ served as the main active site for the PDH reaction, and Mg doping increased the total alkalinity of the catalyst, which promoted the desorption of propylene, thereby enhancing its selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Large-scale exploitation of natural gas and shale gas has spurred the development of the propane dehydrogenation technology. While cobalt-based catalysts, known for their low cost and low toxicity, effectively activate C–H bonds, they are often deactivated because of coke formation. In this study, we prepared SBA-15 molecular sieves using a hydrothermal synthesis method and developed a series of Co-based catalysts supported on SBA-15 with various metal promoters (denoted Co-X/SBA-15, where X = Mn, Fe, Mg, Zn, or La) via an incipient wetness impregnation method. Characterization techniques and activity evaluation results revealed that the Co–O–Mg structure in the Co-Mg/SBA-15 catalyst stabilizes the primary Co2+ active site and hinders the reduction of the CoOx species. The incorporation of Mg enhances the total alkalinity of the catalyst, facilitating propane adsorption and propylene desorption, leading to superior activity and stability. Although the addition of La improved propylene selectivity, it did not significantly enhance propane conversion. Conversely, the introduction of Mn, Fe, and Zn into the catalyst inhibited the reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Impact of various metal promoters on the propane dehydrogenation performance of cobalt-based catalysts
